title: Teaching and supervision
text:
I regularly teach epidemiology and statistics on the UCL MSc in Clinical Mental Health Sciences and MSc in Mental Health Sciences Research. I am co-deputy lead of the MSc module Epidemiology Research Methods in Mental Health (PSBS0013) and teaches statistics on the Core Principals of Mental Health Research MSc module (PSBS0002).
I am also a committee member for the UCL Clinical Data Science Technology Platform training where I have co-designed and taught on a series of workshops on using primary care databases for research at UCL.



I guest lecture on the MSc in Mental Health Research at the University of Sussex where I teach medical records research.



In 2023 I co-designed and taught on a one-day workshop on using R for epidemiological research in collaboration with MQ and DATAMIND. Recordings of the day can be found here. In 2025, I returned to the event to present a lecture on data harmonisation.

title: A Scottish research visit
text:
This past week I have been in Edinburgh and Glasgow. While I’ve been to Edinburgh many times, this was my first visit to Glasgow. The photo on this post is from the amazing street art walk I went on on Sunday.
As well as a bit of sight-seeing, I also managed to catch up with colleagues at the University of Edinburgh where I presented on cardiovascular disease and cancer in people with severe or complex mental illness. You can watch the talk here.
I also went to the Mental Health Platform research summit where I presented our target trial emulation of statins for symptom improvement in people with severe mental illness. It was a real challenge to fit it all into a three-minute flash talk, so I made a poster too. All the code, the poster, the pre-print etc are on my GitHub page here!
And finally, tomorrow I am moving on to the Health Data Research UK conference where I am looking forward to catching up with colleagues in the Big Data for Complex Disease programme and hearing about the evolving state of health care data in the UK.

title: Our pledge for the HDR UK Black Internship programme
text:
This week we submitted our pledge for the HDR UK Black Internship programme. This programme offers a paid 8-week internship in data science, alongside training, networking and collaborative opportunities.
I don’t yet know what our project will be - something around the intersection of physical and mental health. We’ll be hosting the successful applicant in the Division of Psychiatry and in the Advanced Research Computing department - both at UCL. I think being based across these two departments should lead to a really broad and interesting experience.
Watch this space for more information!

title: Approval to access NHS data through the British Heart Foundation data science centre
text:
My latest data application has been approved. This exciting body of work will allow us to say more about how heart failure is diagnosed for people with severe or complex mental illness and how that affects the risk of dying from this disease. The work is really exciting because of the wealth of data we will have access to. This includes GP and hospital data, death certificate data, but also heart failure registry data and mental health services data.
As well as working with the collaborators from my fellowship, I am pleased to work with Dr Kelly Fleetwood, a statistician at the University of Edinburgh who has been working with the BHF Data science centre to study SMI and heart disease, and Dr Ramesh Nadarajah an academic clinical lecturer in cardiology at Leeds University and a fellow HDR UK fellow.

title: Approval to access NHS data through the British Heart Foundation data science centre
text:
My latest data application has been approved. This exciting body of work will allow us to say more about how heart failure is diagnosed for people with severe or complex mental illness and how that affects the risk of dying from this disease. The work is really exciting because of the wealth of data we will have access to. This includes GP and hospital data, death certificate data, but also heart failure registry data and mental health services data.
As well as working with the collaborators from my fellowship, I am pleased to work with Dr Kelly Fleetwood, a statistician at the University of Edinburgh who has been working with the BHF Data science centre to study SMI and heart disease, and Dr Ramesh Nadarajah an academic clinical lecturer in cardiology at Leeds University and a fellow HDR UK fellow.

title: Approval to access NHS data through the British Heart Foundation data science centre
section: Why focus on people with severe or complex mental illness?
text:
Why focus on people with severe or complex mental illness?
People with severe mental illness are at increased risk of heart disease. Once diagnosed they are also less likely to receive the best treatment, more likely to have multiple hospital stays and more likely to die due to their heart disease.
Despite this, we don’t know very much about how well heart failure is diagnosed in people with severe or complex mental illness. We know for cancer, people with severe mental illness are less likely to attend screening and more likely to be diagnosed at a late stage. We want to find out if the same is true for heart failure, because like cancer, early diagnosis of heart failure is key in improving heart failure outcomes.

What might the data tell us?
We think the numbers of patients with severe mental illness will likely be small, but the ability to link rich cohort data with electronic health records will be really valuable. It should enable us to take a closer look at who does and doesn’t attend cancer screening and physical health checks - hopefully informing targeted approaches to improve screening in people with mental health conditions.
Read more about the planned research on the BHF data science centre website!.

title: Open science
text: I’m passionate about open science and sharing what I am doing. If you have a question about mental health data science and in particular electronic health records then do get in touch!

title: Open science
text:
GitHub
I have shared much of my code for cleaning and analysing CPRD data on my GitHub page. All of my fellowship research will also be shared here. Please do give it a look and feel free to get in contact if you have queries.

title: Open science
text:
Open science framework
I pre-publish my study protocols on the Open Science Framework wherever possible. Take a look at what I am working on here.

title: Open science
text:
Pre-print servers
I pre-print my manuscripts on servers such as MedRxiv.

title: Open science
text:
Code list repositories
While many of my code lists are available on GitHub, I have additionally published many of them on the HDR UK phenotype library.

title: Open science
text:
Team science approaches
I am to be collaborative and approachable in everything I do. I enjoy working as a team, and working across disciplines and expertise. In my fellowship I am drawing heavily on those with expertise in cancer and cardivascular disease epidemiology, on people with lived experience of mental and physical health conditions, and of the clinical expertise of colleagues in the Division of Psychiatry at UCL.
I am also part of an exciting NIHR funded Team Science award, working with a diverse group of researchers across England to better understand the interplay of mental health, medications and mobility.

title: IMPARTED: Improving Mental and Physical health Analytics through RobusT Epi and Data sci
text:
Naomi Launders
I am an epidemiologist and data scientist with over 15 years experience using electronic health records to answer complex public health questions.
My work sits at the interface of data science, public health and epidemiology, and at the interface of physical and mental health.
I am currently funded by an HDR UK Fellowship as part of the Big Data for Complex Disease driver programme.
My current research focuses on using electronic health records, census and cohort data to better study the screening, diagnosis, treatment and outcomes of cancer and cardiovascular disease in people with severe mental illness.
My research interests include:


The use of electronic medical records and other routinely collected data in epidemiology
The physical health of people with mental illness
Health care access and utilisation in people with mental illness
Drug repurposing and target trial emulation
Psychiatric epidemiology
Pharmacoepidemiology
Causal inference in observational data


Read about me and my research on:
LinkedIn
The UCL website
The HDR UK website

title: Naomi’s CV/resume
text:
Here is the most recent version of my CV/resume. Information on my teaching experience, supervision, invited talks, publications and collaborations can be found elsewhere on this website.

Personal profile
I am an HDR-UK funded research fellow and epidemiologist, with extensive experience of using R and Stata to analyse complex healthcare datasets. I have strong project management and interpersonal skills and have experience of working with a wide range of stakeholders. I am committed to open science, the team science approach, and building skills in others.

title: Science club
text:
When I am not putting my coding skills to use trying to solve complex epidemiological issues, I lead a science club at a local Primary School where I teach 9-11 year olds to use Python and build and drive go karts!


Our team compete in the Kent First Lego League Tournament each year. Occasionally the team has even reached the national finals! The competition has two main parts; the Robot challenge and the innovation challenge.

title: Science club
text: Our team compete in the Kent First Lego League Tournament each year. Occasionally the team has even reached the national finals! The competition has two main parts; the Robot challenge and the innovation challenge.

title: Science club
text:
Go karts
After the Lego League finishes we pack away and change gear (metaphorically, our go karts only have one speed - fast!)
The children compete in the Young Eco Engineers go kart race. This starts with building the Go Kart from a kit. The children learn to drill, cut and screw, to measure and use a wide range of tools. We then choose a theme and decorate the kart. They spend hours on the playground honing their driving skills as well as time indoors writing in their engineering workbooks. The engineering workbooks ask about key engineering principles, the environment, team work, and kart design. Finally, race day, the adults drive to Gillingham, where we race against 11 other teams around a circuit. There is always drama on the track, but our mini-racers stay cool and collected and often bring home a trophy!

title: When the Dr doesn’t call
text: Our latest research has found that almost 28% of people with severe mental illness are removed from the totals used to calculate how many people have been offered physical health screening. Men, younger people, white people and people who had a diagnosis of psychosis not due to schizophrenia or bipolar disorder were particularly likely to be removed from the totals, and those with a diagnosis of schizophrenia were likely to be removed due to informed dissent.

title: When the Dr doesn’t call
text:
The world of pay-for-results
Doctors practices in England receive payments for achieving results. These include things like offering stop smoking services to all smokers and making sure that people with heart conditions are getting the right treatment. For people with severe mental illness (SMI), GPs receive payments if all people with SMI have a health check.
But, some people might not want that health check, and others might not be suitable for the health check. To make it fair across all GP practices. doctors can remove these people from their tally.

title: When the Dr doesn’t call
section: Why are we interested in who isn’t included?
text:
Why are we interested in who isn’t included?
Removing people who don’t need these health checks makes sense if they truly don’t need them. Equally, if someone is making an informed decision not to have a health check, that’s also fine. But, just because a patient doesn’t attend their appointment doesn’t mean they don’t need or want their physical health checked. There are lots of potential reasons why someone might not respond to an invitation, or might miss an appointment.

title: When the Dr doesn’t call
text:
What do our findings mean?
The proportion of patients removed for “informed dissent” appears to be increasing. However, whether this truly represents informed dissent is hard to work out. Some people with severe mental illness may be missing invitations due to their poor mental health. If they are recorded as “informed dissent” they may not be contacted again for physical health screening in that year. While a GP still has duty of care for people who are removed from the totals, more needs to be done to ensure those people who may struggle to respond to invitations to screening, to book appointments, or to attend the GP practice have access to these important screening programmes every year.

title: Social prescribing in England
text:
Our latest research, led by Feifei Bu and Alex Burton shows that social prescribing is growing fast, and has surpassed government targets for the roll-out.
Social prescribing usually starts with a referral from a GP to a link worker. From there, people may be offered access to a variety of activities. These include art classes, music sessions, gardening groups and gym membership, but there are many more activities available. You can read more about them on the National Academy for Social Prescribing website.
Our research found that there have been 5.5 million referrals to social prescribing since the scheme began, and that referrals for people in the most deprived areas have been increasing year on year. In 2023, 1.3 million people were referred to social prescribing, while 12% refused the service. Refusals for the service appear to be reducing, while the number of referrals for people in the most deprived areas are increasing.
It looks like social prescribing is well received, though further research is required to assess whether it is reaching the groups who need it most, and whether it is making long-term differences to the quality of life for people with long-term health conditions. In particular, we are interested to see how well it is used for people with severe mental illness.
Read the full paper here.

title: Social prescribing in England
text:
Our latest research, led by Feifei Bu and Alex Burton shows that social prescribing is growing fast, and has surpassed government targets for the roll-out.
Social prescribing usually starts with a referral from a GP to a link worker. From there, people may be offered access to a variety of activities. These include art classes, music sessions, gardening groups and gym membership, but there are many more activities available. You can read more about them on the National Academy for Social Prescribing website.
Our research found that there have been 5.5 million referrals to social prescribing since the scheme began, and that referrals for people in the most deprived areas have been increasing year on year. In 2023, 1.3 million people were referred to social prescribing, while 12% refused the service. Refusals for the service appear to be reducing, while the number of referrals for people in the most deprived areas are increasing.
It looks like social prescribing is well received, though further research is required to assess whether it is reaching the groups who need it most, and whether it is making long-term differences to the quality of life for people with long-term health conditions. In particular, we are interested to see how well it is used for people with severe mental illness.
Read the full paper here.

title: Fellowship research with the UK LLC
text: Work on my Health Data Research UK (HDR UK) fellowship is now underway. We have approval to look at cancer screening and cardiovascular disease risk factor screening using data from the UK Longitudinal Linkage Collaboration. I now have access to their novel data - linking many of the UK longitudinal cohort studies to medical records for over 400,000 people.

title: Fellowship research with the UK LLC
text: Work on my Health Data Research UK (HDR UK) fellowship is now underway. We have approval to look at cancer screening and cardiovascular disease risk factor screening using data from the UK Longitudinal Linkage Collaboration. I now have access to their novel data - linking many of the UK longitudinal cohort studies to medical records for over 400,000 people.

title: Fellowship research with the UK LLC
text:
What might it tell us?
We think the numbers of patients with severe mental illness will likely be small, but the ability to link rich cohort data with electronic health records will be really valuable. It should enable us to take a closer look at who does and doesn’t attend cancer screening and physical health checks - hopefully informing targeted approaches to improve screening in people with mental health conditions.
Read more about the planned research on the UK LLC website!.
Exciting to look at this in collaboration with Prof David Osborn and Prof Joe Hayes at UCL, Prof Ann John at Swansea University and Dr Caroline Jackson at University of Edinburgh.

title: Publications
text:
Read our two DATAMIND reports on the use of routine data (Electronic Health Records and longitudinal studies) to study severe mental illness and cardiovascular disease risk factors. They highlight the strengths and challenges of these data, complexities of defining SMI and differences in recording of SMI, and cardiovascular disease risk factors across the four nations.



In 2023, I co-authored a report with OHID on all-cause mortality in people with severe mental illness during the COVID-19 pandemic:
Premature mortality during COVID-19 in adults with severe mental illness
